Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Colin,
 
First, thanks for your contributions.  You've been a great help in
developing my understandings of NEAT.  (I hope that is a compliment).
 
Are you saying (in effect) that Lp Norms are a good collection of "distance"
metrics for genomes?  I think these may have value in roulette wheel
application to allele pattern probabilities.
 
Ken Lloyd


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Colin
Green
Sent: Sunday, December 21, 2008 4:13 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Genome compatibility and Euclidean distance



Hi all,

If you consider a genome instance to be a point in a multidimensional
space then perhaps Euclidean distance is a sensible/reasonable metric
to use when calculating similarity between genomes when determining if
they are in the same species or not.

So where we have matching connection genes the connection weights
would be the locations on an axis and where we have disjoint genes
this could be taken as one of the genomes being at position 0 on that
particular axis. I think currently people are using linear weightings
to calcualte compatibility between matching connections, am I right or
have things moved on?

Thoughts?

Colin.
